thread.title: Contractor guts wrong Fort Worth home, offers to restore it
thread.title_full: Contractor guts wrong Fort Worth home, offers to restore it

author: Eline de Bruijn
title: Contractor guts wrong Fort Worth home, offers to restore it
text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
Two Fort Worth property owners called police when they thought burglars had destroyed their rental house and stripped it of appliances, toilets, shutters, doors, molding, furniture and even the front doorbell. 
Lee and Lelia Beckelman, who are from the Houstoh area, had a contract to sell the house in the 2700 bock of Forest Park Boulevard, near the Texas Christian Unviersity campus, according to the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. Their real estate agent found discovered earlier this month that the property had been stripped -- with only walls, bathtubs and some of the flooring remaining. 
As a burglary investigation began, Fort Worth police received a call from a contractor who explained what happened, according to the Star-Telegram . 
The contractor, who was not identified, told police he had been hired to gut a nearby house. Although the address on the curb matched that home, the numbers on the house were different. "2700 Forest Park Blvd" is written on the curb in front of the house, which has a different address. Google Maps 
“It was a huge misunderstanding,” Fort Worth police Sgt. W. D. Paine told the Star-Telegram . 
The man who owned the home that was supposed to be dismantled didn’t give the contractor a key and told him to kick the door in to get inside, Paine said. So that’s what the contractor did, and his crew finished the job in three days. 
“We can’t really file a criminal mischief charge because his intent wasn’t to deprive them of the property,” Paine said to the Star-Telegram . “We’re leaving it up to the contractor and victim to settle it.” 
Police don’t intend to charge the contractor for the mistake. The homeowners have spoken with the contractor, and he has offered to restore the house or buy it for the selling price. 
It was listed for $369,000, Lelia Beckelman told the Star-Telegram . The Beckelmans plan on the contractor returning everything that had been taken and restore the house. 
“He feels really bad and is willing to make us whole and restore things,” Beckelman said to the Star-Telegram . “He’s an honest guy.” Zillow
